thread.title: Utah football: Utes have surrendered just two sacks this season
thread.title_full: Utah football: Utes have surrendered just two sacks this season | Deseret News

author: Dirk Facer
title: Utah football: Utes have surrendered just two sacks this season
text:
Fourth-ranked Utah takes on an Arizona State squad that registered eight last week against Colorado.
Upcoming Games Utah Football Utah football stats & schedule ASU @ Utah Rice-Eccles Stadium, Salt Lake City Oct. 17, 8:00 p.m. 1  Day   11  Hrs   51  Mins   42  Secs More Coverage Enemy camp: 5 questions with an ASU beat writer Utes, underdogs no longer, playing with a chip on their shoulders Utah vs. Arizona St. in 6 numbers “ The passing game involves all 11 people.”
Utah offensive line coach and co-coordinator Jim Harding
SALT LAKE CITY — Through five games, the fourth-ranked Utah Utes have given up just two sacks — good enough to rank them in a tie for third nationally.
Offensive line coach and co-coordinator Jim Harding insists there are plenty of reasons for the successful pass protection. He said it’s not just the offensive line. Harding noted that running backs are asked to protect at all times; the quarterbacks have done a nice job of knowing where the progression is and getting rid of the football; and the wide receivers are getting open.
“The passing game involves all 11 people,” Harding said.
Case in point, last week’s 54-yard touchdown pass from Travis Wilson to Cory Butler-Byrd in Utah’s 30-24 win over California. Harding pointed to a well-timed isolated block from running back Joe Williams for making it happen.
“It’s a whole offensive accomplishment,” Harding said. “But we’ve got to be ready this week.”
Utah’s opponent this week — Arizona State — recorded eight sacks against Colorado last Saturday.
The Utes counter with senior center Siaosi Aiono. He’s credited for being a “wizard” out on the field for adjusting protections and pointing out blitzes and such.
“That dude is smart and you’ve got to give a lot of credit to him,” said starting right tackle J.J. Dielman. “Because he’s the brains of the organization. We just do what we’re told.”
MISSION MAN: Freshman wide receiver Britain Covey made it clear this week that he is still planning to serve an LDS Church mission after the season — confirming such in a statement on Twitter. He’ll file his papers soon and hopes to depart in March.
“I made the decision a long time ago, regardless of how well this season went for me and my team,” Covey’s tweet read in part. “. . . The Lord has blessed me with so much. For me personally, the least I can do is step away from football for a few years and focus on completely devoted service to Him.”
Covey is currently second on the team with 17 receptions for 182 yards. He has two touchdown catches.
MAKING AN IMPACT: Former Utah star Paris Warren , who was co-offensive MVP in the Fiesta Bowl victory along with Alex Smith , is back with the Utes this season as a student assistant while completing work on his degree. Whittingham said Warren is doing a great job assisting the receivers. He’s also been a good sounding board for running back Devontae Booker . Warren and Booker grew up in the same neighborhood in Sacramento, California, and call themselves “cousins” after developing a close friendship over the years.
“We talk about everything,” Booker said.
EXTRA POINTS: The Utah men’s and women’s basketball teams will be recognized during a break in Saturday’s game . . . Officials are already announcing that the 35th consecutive sellout crowd at Rice-Eccles Stadium will be on hand . . . The team will wear a “Ute Proud” decal on their helmets against ASU.
